string_table.string: Skip Navigation. Hit enter to return to the slide.

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: Hello everyone! Welcome to the lecture on literature review. This lecture is designed by Dr. Candace Chou and narrated by Dr. Karen Kozen-Lien.

The objectives of this lecture are to:

• Understand the purpose of literature review

• Develop methods in finding related literature

• Analyze and summarize previous studies

• Plan for your own literature review

Why is it important to conduct literature review before conducting our own research? Reviewing existing literature can help us identify research questions, inform us about various methodology, findings, and conclusions. Most importantly, we conduct a literature review to make connection of our own research with previous research. By comparing our proposed study with previous investigation or review of literature, we can establish the significance of the problem under investigation and place the study in an appropriate context.

There are many reasons to conduct a literature review. For example,

• The review can reveal investigations similar to your own, and how other researchers handled these similar situations.

• Introduces you to the significant figures in the field.

• See the problem in historical context.

• Helps you evaluate your own work compared to the efforts of others.

• Other studies may suggest methodologies against which you can compare your design.

• Other studies can suggest ways to handle problems that might arise in your sampling, data gathering, or statistical analysis.

• Perhaps most important: You get a full context of the way the problem has been investigated in the past.

The literature review should include (as appropriate):

• Historical context. How does a research problem become a main issue and what are the root causes?

• Major figures in the field. Who are the theorists or main researchers in the field?

• Origins of the key concepts or terms. You can provide clear definitions of the key terms.

• Major studies that provide a picture of the field. If possible, be sure to cite ground-breaking research or major studies that have high frequency of citations.

You can organized the literature review in some logical fashion, either by chronologically order or by sub-topics.

Here are a few quick steps to find relevant literature to the topic of your interests.

First you select the topic and key terms. For example, reviewing literature on student motivation, you can also look up key words on engagement, sense of belonging, effort, self-efficacy.

Second, you identify databases to conduct your research. ERIC, also known as Education Resources Information Center, is a popular database. Other sources such as PsyInfo or Academic Search Premier are all good sources for educational research. Try to make an appointment with a librarian, whose expertise can really save you time in finding relevant literature.

Third, It is also a good idea to use a thesaurus to find more relevant terms. Most library databases have built-in thesaurus tool to assist you in expanding your search.

Finally, go ahead and conduct the research.

In the next slides, you will learn a few strategies for organizing your literature review.

Your can use a worksheet to assist you in determining the main concepts and the related descriptors for your research. In this slide, you can see a few key concepts related to the topic of “parental influence on cognitive development of pre-school children.”

There are three main concepts: preschool children, parents, and cognitive development.

Under each main concept, you can develop a few more key word or descriptors that can be used in the library search. For example, other ways to call “preschool children” can be “preschoolers,” “toddlers,” “early childhood,” or “young children.”

We can also expand the search for “parents” using descriptors such as “parental role,” “parent child relationship,” or “parent influence.”

Other ways to call “cognitive development” include “mental development,” “moral development,” or “school readiness.” You see by listing the main concepts, you can brainstorm to come up with a few descriptors for your library search.

A review map is a great way for visual learners to organize the structure of the literature review. For example, in this study on digital equity, I started with a theoretical framework on digital equity to examine existing theories or framework on this topic.

Next, based on the studies from the past five years, I organized them into three sub-topics that examine digital equity from the angle of disparity in home access and usage, digital literacy, teacher training, and leadership.

I then continued to review the opportunities and challenges of digital equity initiatives from the past ten years. I also have a section on the overview of digital tutoring which is the main focus of my study.

Finally, the literature review should end with a summary of major studies/findings mentioned in the literature review. The structure of the concept map can be determined by the issues related to your research problem or dictated by your findings.

It is also very helpful to develop a literature matrix in documenting your findings during literature review. You may not want to make a decision as to which study to include in your literature review until after you have reviewed enough studies. You can summarize all the studies you have scanned in a table format similar to the one on this slide to help you make a quick decision on what to include in your literature review paper.

Now take a minute to think about a possible topic for your literature review. Come up with two or three concept and the descriptors for each main concept. You will then bring this table to a librarian to help you refine the list.

Your can use a worksheet to assist you in determining the main concepts and the related descriptors for your research. In this slide, you can see a few key concepts related to the topic of “parental influence on cognitive development of pre-school children.” There are three main concepts: preschool children, parents, and cognitive development. Under each main concept, you can develop a few more key word or descriptors that can be used in the library search. For example, other ways to call “preschool children” can be “preschoolers,” “toddlers,” “early childhood,” or “young children.” We can also expand the search for “parents” using descriptors such as “parental role,” “parent child relationship,” or “parent influence.” Other ways to call “cognitive development” include “mental development,” “moral development,” or “school readiness.” You see by listing the main concepts, you can brainstorm to come up with a few descriptors for your library search.

A good literature should consisted of mainly studies from primary sources. They are original studies by researchers in peer-review or refereed journals or dissertation research databases. Secondary sources usually refer to professional books such as textbooks, encyclopedias, book reviews, yearbooks, handbooks, or meta-analysis. A meta-analysis is a review that uses statistical methods to synthesize previous research.

You can usually find references to primary sources from secondary sources.

The Lit Reviews of other studies provide a great sense of perspective. Try to steer clear of “opinion pieces” and secondary sources. You want to review original research to learn about updates in the field.. Be sure to read the studies and write your review from your own personal critique.
Now pause for a few seconds to determine which of the following is a primary or secondary source. Place a P for primary or S for secondary next to each item.

There are three essential strategies in writing a good literature review. Emphasizing relatedness of previous studies to the proposed research, providing objective critiques, and offering meaningful summary. We will look at each strategy in the next three slides.

Emphasizing Relatedness

It’s important to:

• Keep readers continually aware of the way this literature relates to your study.

• Use segues to connect studies, making it readable. Make sure there’s a transition from one study to the next study so it reads more smoothly.

• Don’t just make a list. Discuss the relationship between the literature and your study. (Each study should have a reason for being cited.)

Critique

• You are reviewing the literature, not just reproducing or listing it.

• Give your readers some sense of the quality, purpose, or value of the study you’re citing.

• Use paraphrase and various techniques to synthesize each study you plan to cite.

• Short quotes are OK, if they further the reader’s understanding.

• Use long quotes as a last resort.

Summary

End your Lit Review with a brief summary that collects the major gist of the collected group of related literature.

At the end of your lit review, readers should have a sense of:

• The landscape of the topic.

• What it means to your study.

• How your study fits.

Here is a quick summary of the keys to successful literature review:

• Good organization.

• Relatedness.

• Connections and Seques.

• Primary research, not opinion pieces.

• Clear and concise writing.

It’s always a good idea to start your literature review with a good outline. In this example on “what is the influence of a whole-language program on students’ desire to read?” we start with introduction to the field by citing a few classic studies, defining the terms, and introduce major figures in the field. Next, the paper is divided into four sub-topics related to whole-language program. The paper then ends with a conclusion.

In this video, we have reviewed:

• Purpose of literature review

• Methods in finding related literature

• Synthesis of previous studies

• Plan for your own literature review
